plist.p: Good morning. We're going to begin the Results Presentation for the Second Quarter of 2012. We will follow the usual procedure. Once the presentations have been given, we'll have questions from the room, then by phone and finally through the website. The event will take an hour and a half, so we expect to finish by 11. And I'm now going to hand the floor over to the Chairman.

Good morning, everyone. Thank you very much for attending this results presentation, both those of you in the room and those that are following it by phone or the website. As usual, I have José Luis San Pedro; and the CFO, José Sáinz Armada, with me. As Ignacio Cuenca said, the presentation will consist in – my presentation with the main highlights for the semester. Then the CFO will give more details on the results and finally we will move on to questions.

The current year, as everyone knows, is extremely complex, both because of the economic crisis we're affected by, especially in the Eurozone and particularly Spain, as well as because of the situation of the power sector in our country. In spite of this, IBERDROLA has continued to improve its results, thanks to an international diversification process which has enabled us to attain in this semester a net profit of €1.8 billion, where the growth is 74% in our International business, which has more than offset the 44% drop in the Spanish business. And the Spanish business contribution represents less than 25% of the results for the group.

Regarding the first semester of 2012, all business have grown except for the liberalised and regulated business in Spain. The liberalised business in Spain has been affected by a 24% drop in output under the Ordinary Regime, as a result mainly of the low hydro output this year. The lower results of the regulated business is mainly a result of the impact of the regulatory measures approved by the government on March 30. And with all this, the group EBITDA in spite of this grew 2% to €4.087 million. What's more important is that the operating cash flow increased 5.8%. And last year, we grew by a similar amount to €3.3 billion, contributing to the strengthening of the liquidity position of the group, which amounts to almost €10 billion, with which we can cover our financial needs for the coming 24 months.

I would also like to highlight the strong commitment taken on by IBERDROLA of maintaining its financial strength in a year characterized by a high degree of uncertainty, which is negatively affecting companies in the sector in Spain. And in view of the very difficult market conditions, flexibility and foresight are best tools to increase solidity. These tools have been very highly valued by the international financial institutions, which has enabled us to continue to pick up resources under very favorable conditions.

As I said earlier, the diversified business model has enabled IBERDROLA to increase its EBITDA as of June 30 to €4 billion, with a growing contribution of the regulated and renewable businesses, which is almost 75% if we include the regulated generation in Mexico. The regulated EBITDA is 5% mostly, thanks to the integration of Elektro since May 2011, which more than offsets the impact of the Royal Decree 13/2012 which represented €117 million less in earnings in the first semester. In renewables, there is a 12% growth in EBITDA as a result of greater output in all the geographic regions where we're present. And this represents an increase of 12.6% for the group compared to the same semester last year. Finally, the liberalised business represents a drop of 4% in spite of the improvement in the United Kingdom as a result of the worst results obtained in Spain, where the higher market prices have not offset the drop in production.

The contribution to EBITDA from the International businesses has been a decisive factor with an increase of 13.4% during the period and with all businesses growing. And I would like to highlight that if we even discount the contribution of Elektro, the EBITDA for the International business increased by 6.6%. On the other hand, developments in Spain have been negative. EBITDA dropped 8.3% during this period. The regulated business had a drop of 13% because of the regulatory measures. The liberalised business dropped its EBITDA by 10%. On the other hand, the EBITDA for renewables in Spain grew 23%, driven by the 11% increase in wind power production, which was favored by the positive developments in wind power resources during the second half of the year.

As mentioned earlier, one of the main objectives for IBERDROLA is to maintain its financial strength and reduce the debt level. And for this, we continue to work on the optimization of the financial structure for the group. We've closed the first half with a liquidity position of €9.551 billion which enables us to cover our financial need for the next two years, as José said earlier, and the average debt maturity is 6.3 years, and the CFO will give us more details on this. We have also reduced leverage, which has gone from 46.4% at the end of 2011 to 46.1%. And this is reflected in our main credit ratios. Lead ratios are also being favored by the good developments in the operating cash flow which, as I said earlier, amounted to €3.3 billion, an increase of 5.8% compared to the same period in 2011.

The net profits increased by 15% to €553 million. This €553 million are mainly from the International business, and we can also highlight the change in the fiscal clause in the United States as a result of a favorable ruling from the tax authorities and the recognition in Brazil of the possibility of deducting the goodwill in the purchasing of Elektro. And additionally, these results include non-recurring expenses of €171 million of – because of the write-down of the investment in Gamesa and the provisions associated to wind power projects which were finally cancelled. So the growth in net profits for the group, as I said, is fundamentally due to the contribution of the International business, €1.363 billion, offsetting the 44% drop in the Spanish results which were up by €438 million, a fourth of the total.

And now, I'll briefly go over the regulatory situation in Spain and in the United Kingdom. In Spain, the tariff deficit problem requires an urgent solution if we want to guarantee the economic sustainability of the system. The uncertainty generated in recent months have taken Spain to risk levels that are having a major effect on the financing of a sector that is as basic as the power sector in our country. In order to tackle this problem, IBERDROLA, as always, is open to collaborating with the administration to adopt new measures, which should be objective and not discriminatory to have an effect on those factors that have generated the deficit. So we need a transparent and interactive model that will have a clear and defined objective and we should first define if the purpose is only to collect more taxes or to optimize and have an efficient operation of the system and the sustainability and safe operation of the system or if the aim is a mere price reduction. We must also consider the effects that this can have on investments in the sector and, therefore, on tax earnings. We need a model that is based on uniform, reasonable and explainable criteria and not discriminatory reasons based on turnover, unit cost, availability of equipment, profitability of the investments, et cetera, et cetera. We also need a model that should be based on reliable and real data from reliable sources, and finally, a model that will take into account the court rulings.

Regarding this latter aspect, in 2012 in June, the Supreme Court has passed three relevant rulings regarding the claims made by solar producer associations. The last of these in June confirms the possibility of modifying the remuneration framework under the special regime in order to maintain reasonable profitability criteria according to Royal Decree 661/2007, which establishes a return rate of 8%. And the ruling says that those rulings and clauses that have effected in the past should not be deployed that will have an effect on future results. And again, the ruling also said, if the new economic circumstances imply adjustments in many other production sectors with obvious difficulties for their activity, it is not unreasonable that those also extend to the renewable energy sector and that wished to continue to receive the regulated tariffs instead of resorting to the market mechanisms, and more so before situations of a generalized economic crisis. And in the case of power, in view of the growth of the tariff deficit, it rises from the impact of the calculation of the access tolls which has an effect on the cost of the power system.

And finally, the text also says that it's logical that faced with any technological modification or before significant changes in the economic situation, the initial determining parameters need to be reviewed in order to calculate the regulated tariff. And the aspect of legal certainty cannot oppose this principle. Therefore, the Supreme Court rejects the possibility of maintaining an unmodifiable economic regime and refers to the economic circumstances and the technological maturity in the same way that this occurs in the United States remuneration regime to avoid unreasonable returns, although the Americans do not talk about retroactivity, but about a remuneration adjustment. And it's well known that the President of the government is a prudent, honest and a man with common sense, and he's having to make brave decisions at this difficult time. Therefore, I trust that he's going to do everything that is necessary to put an end to this scourge of the tariff deficit and, as he said, through a model that will be economically and environmentally sustainable. So it doesn't seem reasonable to have a cheap power station shutdown. While power stations are in production, the energy of which costs us seven or eight times more, such as the case of some solar plants. So as I said, the deficit problem will only be solved by acting on the factors that caused it and not on those that are outside the area.

In the United Kingdom, on the other hand, important steps have been taken in defining a predictable and stable regulatory framework for some of the sector activities. In the grid business, we have regulatory stability, both transmission and distribution, with tariff frameworks that will be enforced up to 2015 and 2021 respectively, thus ensuring a sufficient and predictable remuneration for the planned investments which in our case amount to – close to €6 billion over the coming years. However, it is necessary to still complete the definition of the regulatory framework for the generation activity in order to offer an adequate remuneration that will provide incentives for the major investment required to replace the obsolete current generation facilities. And in this sense, we need to continue with the reform of the electric power market to establish a sufficient remuneration framework, both for our nuclear and combined gas plants, and renewable plants as of 2014. In the case of renewable plants, they have a transient period between 2013 and 2017, and the remuneration framework called Renewables Obligation Banding Review has been made public today with a sufficient remuneration adapted to the degree of technological maturity, as we have defended over the last few months.
And now, I'm going to hand the floor over to the CFO, José Sáinz Armada, who will explain the results in greater detail.

Thank you very much, Chairman. Good morning. As we can see and as the Chairman said, in spite of the difficult economic conditions that we are going through in Europe, the group continues to grow in its operating lines and cash flow. Elektro contributed to the results in the first half of 2012. Last year, it contributed since the month of May and the exchange rate is also favorable since 53% of the EBITDA in these first six months is outside the Eurozone, which is an important characteristic in this group. Therefore, we've been favored by the revaluation of the dollar and the pound although we are partially affected by the devaluation of the real. And as the Chairman said, there are non-recurrent items that have an impact on net profit and the details of which I'll give later on.

Sales increased 9.3% to €16.992 billion and purchasing 14% to €10.595 billion. The gross margin grew 3.2% to €6.309 billion, including a positive impact of €112 million due to the exchange rate. Excluding this effect, the businesses contributed a further €83 million. The main items responsible for this growth are Renewable and regulated businesses and especially the International business. Our growth is 9.1% in the UK, 9.7% in the United States and 41% in Brazil, with the greater contribution of Elektro. Renewables grew 9.1% in gross margin. This offsets the weak performance of the business in Spain, showing reductions in the gross margin, both in the liberalised business, 11.8%, and the regulated business, 8.3%, because of the lower output and regulatory impact. The 2.3% increase because of the increase in emission rights assigned has fallen by 46% because of the lower price. The net operating cost grew 5.7%. The consolidation of Elektro continues to have an unfavorable impact since it's being consolidated since May 2011. The exchange rate has increased the net operating cost by €32 million.

In the operating cost item, personnel rose 4.8% to €886 million. However, here we have some non-recurring effects linked to restructuring costs and the efficiency measures, which carried a greater weight during the first quarter, which were diluted during the year and which will have a positive impact in the coming years. Net outside services grew 6.5% to €914 million and as well as the Elektro impact, we have a seasonal effect associated through storms and maintenance work in the United States.

Regarding levies, they dropped 6.6% to €481.5 million after the impact resulting from the ruling of the Supreme Court regarding the social bonus, which – most of which was registered during the first quarter. However, as we'll see later on, we continue to pay higher levies, both in Spain and in the United Kingdom. As explained by the Chairman, the 2% growth in EBITDA is based on our diversified business model with renewables and the regulated business, which includes the generated business in Mexico contributing 74% of the total EBITDA. And the EBITDA of the International business is almost 55% of the total.

Starting with the EBITDA of the regulated business, which was almost €2 billion, and 66% of which comes from outside Spain, that is from the United Kingdom, United States and Brazil, the United Kingdom grew 8.2%, United States 6.5%, and Brazil 36%, because of the incremental contribution of Elektro. These advances in the International area offset the lower contribution of our business in Spain. The EBITDA of the regulated business in Spain dropped 12.6% to €682 million because of the cutback of €117 million during the first six months, and during the year this will increase in the remuneration of the business according to Royal Decree 12/2012. The gross margin dropped 8.3% because of this impact. The net operating expenses grew 4.5%. As I said earlier here, we include higher maintenance costs and other costs related to efficiency measures that will have a positive impact in the coming years. Additionally, and this is something we want to highlight, levies in this business also increased 13.7% because of the higher local levies. The regulated UK business obtained an EBITDA of €446 million with an increase of 8.2% associated to greater investments and the positive effect of the exchange rate, €21 million.

The net operating expenses increased €11 million, including expenses resulting from the need to comply with the quality standards linked to DPCR5, part of which have been transferred to the rates. And also because of the exchange rates, the regulated business in the United States provided an EBITDA of €356 million according to the IFRS regulations, which is equivalent to a growth of 6.5% including €24 million because of the exchange rate. The underlying evolutions has also been positive regarding gross margin with €13 million linked to higher returns and the incremental remuneration of the main line. Regarding the GON, it grew 14.9% because of the expenses as a result of the storms last year and the revaluation of the dollar. EBITDA in Brazil grew 36.1% to €495 million with Elektro included in the perimeter since May 2011. This has represented €124 million more in this semester. Additionally, the 6.1% growth in power demand in our area, the positive tariff readjustments at the generators and the greater unit margins are other factors that have contributed to growth. The exchange rate impact in this case is negative and €22.4 million. The net operating expenses grew 54.3% to €203 million, of which a significant part is due to Elektro and the rest is related to cost inflation and a higher activity. Excluding the impact of Elektro and the exchange rate, the recurring EBITDA in Brazil grew 2.6%, or 7% with a homogeneous exchange rate.

Moving on to the liberalised business that includes Spain, the UK and Mexico, EBITDA falls – and here we include Mexico because of reporting issues, EBITDA falls by 4.2% and now stands at €1.2 billion. Spain provides 66% of the EBITDA. The main growth factor in June is still the United Kingdom that provides 19% and this has had a very important recovery as regards to previous fiscal year. The business in Mexico provides 15%, with a positive impact in accordance with the rate of exchange for the positive business. And the net operating expenses have grown 5.2% because of an increase in the trading expenses. Levies show a decline of 18.8%, which is lower than the figure presented in March because of the positive impact of the court resolution.

And starting off now with the liberalised business in Spain, demand in Spain has fallen 0.3% although it's 1.5% when adjusted. The ordinary regime production figures have been reduced by 24.4% as a consequence of a drop of 57.1% in high-quality production and more than 67% in combined cycle production that has been partially offset by an increase in nuclear power and coal, although we have very little in Spain. Prices have gone up a little bit also because of the generation mix and they now stand about €60.

In 2012, all the production has been sold at prices similar to those of the first semester. The basic margin falls 13.1%, also affected by capacity collections that are reduced by €7.5 million, also affected by the Royal Decree. However, the reduction of levies in part offsets the decline in the basic margin. However, after excluding the impact of the social bonus, the levies paid by the business are increased by 10%. So we've increased levies in the transmission and generation business in Spain in a recurrent manner.

The basic margin of the liberalised business in the UK now stands at €598 million, thanks to the retail business with its margins recovering from the minimum levels of 2011 because of the improvement and procurement costs and because of the increase in rates of August 2011. That includes €26 million in positive effects in the rate of exchange and these effects have been partially compensated by a 14% reduction in production because of shutdowns and because of lower spreads that have affected the wholesale and generation business.

Net operating expenses have gone up 7.5% and now stand at €290 million and they include non-recurrent effects that affect the annual comparison. So the business' EBITDA has recovered partially and now stands at €242 million. However, we still have very tight business margins. And it was only 2.1% as regard to EBIT relative to sales, recovering in relation to 2011, which was negative, although very far away from the levels reported for 2010.

EBITDA in Mexico has grown 8.4% and now stands at €131 million. The rate of exchange has added another €13 million to the EBITDA and the gross margin grows 10.6%. And the evolution of the business after excluding the exchange rate effect is also positive because of the heat breaks and because of the increases in plant capacity, although there have been some shutdowns. There are also some non-recurrent maintenance costs, which have penalized the net operating expenses in such amounts that the EBITDA has grown somewhat less than the growth we've had in the – the growth in the gross margin. EBITDA in our renewables business has grown 12.2%. And this is thanks to a very good second quarter.

On the whole, production grows 12.6% with an average load factor of 28.7%, which improved 27.4% of the same periods of previous fiscal year, which means that the EBITDA of the wind business has grown 19.7%. The average price also has gone up, up to €69.1 per megawatt hour because of the change, because of the modifications of the rate of exchange. Operating capacity now stands at 13,560 megawatts and installed capacity has reached 14,171 megawatts.

Operating expenses have improved with a drop of 0.9%, because we've had less non-recurrent expenses. And efficiency improvements also show that the GON megawatt ratio has improved to 4%. The EBIT of the group has dropped 3.3%, which has a worse evolution than EBITDA because of an increase of 142% in provisions, fundamentally linked to the integration of Elektro and some non-recurrent provisions basically in Brazil, and other measures that have to do with promotion of the pipeline as the President pointed out, which affects the United States and which reached €44 million.

So on the whole, non-recurrent provisions are for Brazil as well as of the pipeline, represents something like €100 million. And an increase of 4.6% in amortizations is due to the integration of Elektro and also because there are larger amortizations brought about by investments in the grid. And this has been in part compensated by the extended life cycle of the wind farms. And we can also see that there has been a negative impact produced by the rate of exchange in terms of provisions and amortizations. The net financial results have grown 17%. And this17% increase is due to two factors; firstly, because there's a lower market value of the hedging factors for rate to exchange, because last year the dollar and the pound were devalued vis-à-vis the euro, whereas this year it has been just the opposite, and this lower market value is something you can see in the financial costs; and secondly, because there's been – there have been more financial expenses because of the greater average of debt relative to the first semester of the previous fiscal year.

Secondly, because there's been a greater cost of the debt after integrating Elektro, so we can say that the cost of the debt has hardly changed relative to the previous year. And the reported net profits have grown 15.2% and now stand at €1.8 billion because of the impact of positive non-recurrence at a fiscal level, partially compensated by measures taken in terms of provisions and in terms of consolidation by the equity method. So now, we're talking about €1.4 billion. We've also taken measures in relation to assets totaling €171 million related to the cost of developing renewables. And secondly, we've also taken actions in relation to the Gamesa portfolio that has to do with the equity method. We have included another €127 billion in the book, and we consider that the prospects arising from the analysis are positive as regards the business in the future.

We have two very significant issues. First, we have the deductibility of the Elektro business after reorganization process carried out in our Brazil organizations. We've had profits of €280 million because we've applied fiscal deductions for the price paid for Elektro. And secondly, we have some fiscal provisions in IBERDROLA USA totaling €142 million after a recent ruling – favorable ruling from the American court in relation to a fiscal lawsuit that has been won and has risen from the purchase of Scottish Power. And we will have a reduction of 1% in the tax rate in the UK, although this is some more of a recurrent nature.

And moving on now to the financial side of things, in the first semester of 2012 there's been a reduction of the tariff deficit totaling €281 million, from €2,991 million to €2,710 million because we've generated another €933 million in terms of new deficit and we've securitized a total of €1,200 million. So the debt now stands at €32 billion. And this has been affected by two factors, by the net variation of the deficit which in this quarter has reached a figure €699 million, and we also have the effect of the rate of exchange that has been €503 million in the quarter. As you can see, this has to do with appreciation of the dollar and the pound. After excluding both effects, the group has generated a net cash flow – positive net cash flow of €834 million in the second quarter of the year. And the increase in the debt reduced by the rate of exchange is also compensated by the fact that the rate of exchange have also include those improved our cash flows, as we pointed out throughout the presentation. So therefore, we are still improving leverage and the FFO debt and RCF debt ratios relative to the previous trimester, and we will believe that we'll obtain the ratio in excess of 20%, that is in terms of FFO debt and RCF debt 16%.

And as the President pointed out, we could also point out our excellent liquidity position. We have €9.5 billion in liquidity and the credit line is available, which allows us to cover more than 24 months of financial needs, especially if we bear in the mind the maturity profile of the debt where we don't have any significant maturities in the midterm. We have less than €500 million in maturities in the second semester of 2012 and the average life of the debt is maintained at 6.3 years since the closing of the 2011 fiscal year, thanks to the active management of the group during the semester.
Now, the President will conclude his remarks.

Thank you very much, Pepe. I think that once again, these results of the first semester show how in this complex macroeconomic environment, especially in the euro area, the internationalization of the company has made it possible for the results to improve. And thanks to this, cash flow has grown 5.8% and now stands at €3.3 billion, which has improved our financial position which is a key element for our business model. On the other hand, net profits totaled €1.8 billion with 74% growth of the International business vis-à-vis a reduction of 40% in Spain. So the International business represents more than three-quarters of the total profits of the group. So considering how successful this strategy has been, this internationalization process will have an influence on our growth in the future and our investments will focus on those countries and businesses that offer a stable and objective regulation. So therefore the – what we'll do is give priority to opportunities based on criteria of security, profitability and short periods of execution. And according to these premises, our investments will go mainly to regulated business and to a less extent to renewables, and all of this within the framework of our firm commitment to strengthen the company's balance sheet.

So based on this commitment, our strategy will be focused on optimizing our financial position through generating free cash flow as the top priority, cutting back on investments, selecting only those that are much more attractive in terms of predictability and profitability. We have to actively manage our portfolio and we have to consider divestitures of assets that are not strategic as we have been doing or we have to hold minority shares in some businesses. We have to maintain our efforts to improving our efficiency. And for that, we will reduce our operating expenses in all the activities and in particular in those areas in which they are much more penalized from a macroeconomic or regulatory perspective.

So with this, what we want to do is reduce our level of indebtedness and we want to go on improving – as the Financial Director said, we want to improve the financial ratios and the liquidity position of the company in order to be able to maintain our remuneration policy to the shareholder, as we've done in recent years. So, these are going to be the basic elements of our upcoming strategic approach that we will present on the Investors Day and we will send out the call once we've – once the reform of the electricity sector has been presented in Spain. And you can be sure that all of us people working for this company will do whatever is required to carry on improving our results in the future.
Thank you very much, and now we're going to move on to your questions.
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. The Q&A session starts now.
Cesar and then Alejandro Vigil at the back of the room.

Good morning, Cesar Gonzales from JB Capital. I have three questions. The first one has to do with regulation. A couple of weeks ago, there were a number of measures in the press that apparently the Ministry of Industry is contemplating. And I would like to know what you think about this. Up to what extent do you believe this information is critical and what do you about – think about the timing of this reform, because it has been postponed for many months? And secondly and also in relation to this issue, should the final impact be as bad as we considered it to be? In other words, it would be several hundreds of millions of euros if the strategic guidelines you've just pointed out – do you think that they could be modified as a consequence and do you think that the shareholder remuneration policy could also change? And also I would like to know something about Brazil, because in The Economist there was a news on the IPO that is being considered. So what is the situation then as regards to the activities in that country? And finally, could you say something about the rate of adaptation for the fiscal year? Thank you very much.

Well, as far as the first question is concerned, I think that I said things very clearly, that in spite of the noise and the rumors and news, there's nothing of what I said before. And I have to repeat this, and that is that I'm sure that these characteristics of that show that the President of the government is a person of common sense and is very fair. So whatever is done – is going to be done has he's pointed out on many occasions, and things are going to be done sustainably from the economic and environmental perspective. But I just wanted to give you a figure, because this year the Spanish people have had an increase of 6%, 7% or 8% in their billed in spite of the fact that the price of power – in other words, what we produce – what we've produced have slumped and in spite of the fact that the prices of grids have been increased because of the Royal Decree of the month of March and they are paying more. But apart from that, we are still funding the – we've provided nearly €2 billion to cover that deficit.
Well, what for?
Well, so that these power stations that produce between €300 or €400 can carry on producing, so that we're shutting down power stations that are producing €50 or €60.

So if we believe that you can maintain a system by this based on subsidies that could total €8 billion or €10 billion or if we think that – well, I think that there is an issue that is not sustainable from the economic or the environmental perspective, even more so when we have Supreme Court rulings that clearly state what you cannot do and when there's a legislation that talks about a reasonable degree of profitability which is the degree of 2007.

So talking about retroactivity or non-retroactivity, and this is something the President of (39:16) the United States, they call that remuneration adjustment. Retroactivity is something that comes from the past, not from the future. So if the technological and economic conditions change or the environmental conditions change, the logical and reasonable thing to think of what you should do is review those parameters, even more so when we all know that they are completely wrong. So I think or I hope and trust that what the government does under the leadership of the President will be firm and balanced and that it will do something that is sustainable in the future.

Now moving on to your second question concerning Brazil, well, this thing about the IPO is nothing new and you know that we've had this shareholder agreement for the last ten years. So any of the partners, whenever they consider that this is pertinent, they can apply for it and we already have a structure in place which is a control block and part of it that – would then be traded on the stock exchange at a given point in time. So this is nothing new and this is something contemplated by the shareholders' plan. And any partners can apply for this measure. And this hasn't taken place in ten years, but in any case a partner could apply for this measure and ten we have (40:33) taxation for 2012 which I think you can answer. Well, the normal rate is something like 25% or 26%, the current rate. So in this semester, it's been much lower. So I suppose it will be – the average will be something like 14% or 15%, I assume.
José Luis, would you like to add anything on the first question?
Well, the information we received is that what has come out is just an internal draft of the Ministry of Industry and that they are reviewing it. In fact, it hasn't been approved yet.

But regarding the levies, the nuclear levy of €10 per megawatt hour, if we work out the numbers, if I take the Garona power plant and if we accept the operating and maintenance costs they've given, which are old, €30 per megawatt hour, we add a levy of €10, we're at €40 megawatt hour. Garona planned recurrent investments that were already included in the budget for the next six years of €60 million, €60 million more that are added because of Fukushima, makes it €120 million, plus the €60 million they have, €180 that they have to amortize in six years, €30 million per year since they produce 3,500 gigawatt hours per year. That means that the cost of this new investment is €10 megawatt hour, €40 they had already, plus €10 in investments, €50. 4% of this environmental levy, Garona has a price then of €52 during the last ten years.
How many years have nuclear power plants had earnings over €52?

Only one year, in 2008. This year, at pool prices of around €54 megawatt hour to which we have to add €3 for power guarantees, that makes it €57 megawatt hour, €58 megawatt hour. The average earning of nuclear power plants has been €47 megawatt hour. So I don't know where those extraordinary earnings come from for the power plants. Where an amortized power plant is going to lengthen its life is going to have a price of around €50 megawatt hour, not including the regional or local taxes, which is another €5 megawatt hour. And regarding the hydraulic levy of €15 megawatt hour, I estimate that during the slump hours, there are many hours where the price is less than the €15 per megawatt hours during the value times. There have been many hours this year at price zero. So what do we have to do with water when the price is under €15 megawatt hour? Throw it away, otherwise we're losing money. A pumping station, I've done the calculations with the prices given by the Chairman of the liberalised business. La Muela – The La Muela power plant with €20, €25 per megawatt hour has a price of around €90 per megawatt hour with the €15 levy. How many hours can a pumping station operate if it has to charge a minimum of €90 megawatt hour and it doesn't contribute a single euro to profit, so zero hours. With these levies, we first of all have a change in the relationship between the price of the technologies and this is going to change the optimization of the energy system in a negative way. And secondly, we are assuming profits and applying levies to those profits when those profits don't exist. So, I think that this has been an initial draft as a ministry and I obviously hope it will be corrected.

Well, I would like to add something. So we are moving in a completely different direction, not in an expansive matter, but rather we want to fully rationalize and solidify our balance sheet.

As regards to securitization of the deficit, well, with all the ideas that you have or just send me a list of all the possibilities, because to date, the situation we have, and this has to be done through the Favve (01:11:19) and there's a brochure that has been sent by the Stock Exchange Commission mentioning a number of issues and what Favve (01:11:25) authorizes is that resort to public or private issues, but that's what we have noticed. But if you have any ideas, I'd love to have them because without a doubt I will present them to the government to see if the issue can also solve the problem. And the third question was what? And yes, I think that that's about €3 billion in the year roughly, and if not it will be along those lines.

And the final question, amortizations and provisions; well, now as far as the provisions are concerned, there are two non-recurrent impacts. So in total, we're talking about something like €95 million that are non-recurrent. So therefore, as far as the semester is concerned, what is recurrent is about €80 million and as regards the year, well, it could be more or less double that figure. And the last question, the merger, well, no, certainly not. None of the scenarios has contemplated a merger.

Well, basically, in renewables that we can lower more or less, and in Spain we can lower it more or less depending on the framework at any specific point in time. Sorry, the power stations. Well, enough to reach the ratios that we want to achieve. And he very clearly explained what we expect FFO over debt, cash flow over debt, et cetera. And we'll do whatever is needed depending on the free cash flow we generate. We will complete that with more – fewer divestments to reach that objective.

Good morning. I think that practically all the questions have been asked. But is Gamesa still strategic or could there possibly be a divestment?

Well, over recent years, we've said that Gamesa for us is a company which apart from the investment is a very major supplier for us. Well, first of all, in the UK, we are the first wind power producer in the UK. We continue to build wind farms. Onshore, this year, there'll be 300 megawatts to 400 megawatts. What are we waiting for?
For combined cycles and nuclear plants to clarify the energy reform.
